docs.lead_paragraph: Many athletes have been led to believe that the strengthening of neck muscles reduces their risk of head injury, but a new study suggests that this is not the case. The belief has been that stronger neck muscles may reduce the sudden acceleration of an athlete's head -- and the risk of brain injury -- that can occur when there is a collision or other accident on the playing field.

headline.main: Tough Neck Won't Save a Fragile Head

docs.abstract: Jamie Mansell of Lincoln University leads study on suggested benefits of strong neck muscles in reducing head injuries from athletic contact; research, which is published in Journal of Athletic Training, finds that stronger neck muscles do not appear to protect against head injuries; drawing (S)
docs.snippet: Many athletes have been led to believe that the strengthening of neck muscles reduces their risk of head injury, but a new study suggests that this is not the case.      The belief has been that stronger neck muscles may reduce the sudden...

docs.lead_paragraph: Researchers say they have taken a step toward developing a reliable vaccine against plague. The disease takes two forms: bubonic, which is spread by flea bites, and the more serious pneumonic, which is spread in the air.

headline.main: New Plague Vaccine: It Works on Guinea Pigs

docs.abstract: Dr Charles J Arntzen of Arizona State University reports development of new vaccination against pneumonic plague; research, which is published in Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences, shows that plague-exposed Guinea Pigs who were vaccinated had nearly 75 percent survival rate for deadly disease (S)
docs.snippet: Researchers say they have taken a step toward developing a reliable vaccine against plague.     The disease takes two forms: bubonic, which is spread by flea bites, and the more serious pneumonic, which is spread in the air.
